DataElement.preferredName: Neoplasm First Recurrence Diagnosis Specimen Acquisition Method Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text name of the procedure used to secure the tissue used for an initial recurrent disease diagnosis.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: An abnormal tissue growth resulted from uncontrolled cell proliferation._._Preceding all others in time or space or degree._Happening again (especially at regular intervals)._The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation._A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.:Preceding all others in time or space or degree.:To occur again.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
Preceding all others in time or space or degree.
Happening again (especially at regular intervals).

Property.preferredDefinition: The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.:A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.

Concepts.definition: The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.
A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: text that describes the method of acquiring the tissue specimen._Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products._The process by which something is acquired or obtained._A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The removal of tissue or fluid with a needle for examination under a microscope.:The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

Concepts.definition: The removal of tissue or fluid with a thin needle for examination under a microscope.
The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Cervical Or Image Guided Biopsy Or Other Biopsy

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Cervical Or Image Guided Biopsy Or Other Biopsy
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Relating to a neck, or cervix, in any sense.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis, using imaging technology.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: Removal and pathologic examination of specimens in the form of small pieces of tissue from the living body.

Concepts.definition: Relating to a neck, or cervix, in any sense.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis, using imaging technology.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical procedure in which part of a lesion is removed for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure in which part of a lesion is removed for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated system generated definition with current NCIt definition. mc 11/12/12

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical procedure in which an entire lesion is removed for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure in which an entire lesion is removed for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cytology; the branch of biology that studies the structure and function of cells.

Concepts.definition: The light microscopic study of normal and abnormal cells in fine needle aspirates (FNAs), body cavity fluids, and smears.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The room or rooms in which the physician and staff provide patient care. The offices include all rooms in the physician's office suite.: Removal of tissue from the endometrial cavity for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: A medical facility where a doctor sees and treats patients.
Removal of tissue from the endometrial cavity for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Fluid withdrawn from a body cavity, organ, cyst, or tumor.

Concepts.definition: Fluid withdrawn from a body cavity, organ, cyst, or tumor.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated definition to current NCIt. 4.10.19 mc

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis. In the case of an endoscopic biopsy, an endoscope is used to obtain the sample.

Concepts.definition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis. In the case of an endoscopic biopsy, an endoscope is used to obtain the sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (TRANZ-yoo-REE-thral ree-SEK-shun) Surgery performed with a special instrument inserted through the urethra.

Concepts.definition: Surgery performed with a special instrument inserted through the urethra.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical excision of one or more lymph nodes. Its most common use is in cancer surgery. (From Dorland, 28th ed, p966)

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of lymph nodes, usually done to assess the spread of cancer.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Uses a thin, low-voltage electrified wire loop to cut out a thin layer of abnormal tissue; generally used to remove abnormal cells on the surface of the cervix.

Concepts.definition: Uses a thin, low-voltage electrified wire loop to cut out a thin layer of abnormal tissue; generally used to remove abnormal cells on the surface of the cervix.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (en-DAHS-ko-pee) The use of a thin, lighted tube (called an endoscope) to examine the inside of the body.: The moist tissue that lines some organs and body cavities (such as the nose, mouth, lungs) and makes mucus (a thick, slippery fluid).: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: A diagnostic or therapeutic procedure in which an endoscope is inserted in a tubular organ to examine the structural architecture and/or remove abnormal tissues.
Mucous membrane.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The puncture of a vein with a needle for the purpose of drawing blood.

Concepts.definition: The collection of blood from a vein, most commonly via needle venipuncture.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (as-per-AY-shun) The removal of a small sample of bone marrow (usually from the hip) through a needle for examination under a microscope.

Concepts.definition: Aspiration of immature hematopoietic elements and blood from the bone marrow.  It is done for the evaluation of hematopoietic disorders and for the evaluation of infectious diseases and cytogenetic studies.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The removal of a tissue sample using a needle with a relatively large diameter, for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: The removal of a tissue sample using a needle with a relatively large diameter, for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Added OBIB alternate name and identifier - DW 03-21-2019

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.: Removal and pathologic examination of specimens in the form of small pieces of tissue from the living body.

Concepts.definition: An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.
The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A sharp pointed device.: The removal of a tissue sample using a needle with a relatively large diameter, for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: A sharp pointed device.
The removal of a tissue sample using a needle with a relatively large diameter, for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical scraping and removal of the inner lining of the uterus through direct dilation of the uterine cervix.

Concepts.definition: A surgical scraping and removal of the inner lining of the uterus through direct dilation of the uterine cervix.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Changed definition to match current NCIt. mc 4.23.19

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical technique used for the resection of posteriorly located uveal melanomas without ciliary body involvement via pars plana vitrectomy.

Concepts.definition: A surgical technique used for the resection of posteriorly located uveal melanomas without ciliary body involvement via pars plana vitrectomy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical technique for the transscleral resection of large, anteriorly located uveal melanomas with ciliary body and/or iris involvement.  This approach is most common when conservative therapy is either unlikely to help, or likely to cause complications.

Concepts.definition: A surgical technique for the transscleral resection of large, anteriorly located uveal melanomas with ciliary body and/or iris involvement. This approach is most common when conservative therapy is either unlikely to help, or likely to cause complications.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical procedure by which tissue or an organ (usually containing a tumor) is removed without rupture from a specific anatomic site.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure by which tissue or an organ (usually containing a tumor) is removed without rupture from a specific anatomic site.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of one or both testicles.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of one or both testicles.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to the lumen or inner part of the rectum.: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to the lumen or inner part of the rectum.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A therapeutic surgical procedure in which the anus, rectum, part of the sigmoid colon, and the regional lymph nodes are removed through abdominal and perineal incisions.: Surgical removal of the rectum.

Concepts.definition: A therapeutic surgical procedure in which the anus, rectum, part of the sigmoid colon, and the regional lymph nodes are removed through abdominal and perineal incisions.
Surgical removal of the rectum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Denoting the front surface of the body; often used to indicate the position of one structure relative to another.: Surgical removal of the rectum.

Concepts.definition: Denoting the front surface of the body; often used to indicate the position of one structure relative to another.
Surgical removal of the rectum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A minimum level or position or degree; less than normal in degree, intensity or amount.: Denoting the front surface of the body; often used to indicate the position of one structure relative to another.: The part of the large intestine measured from the cecum to the rectum consisting of ascending, transverse, descending and sigmoid portions. The purpose of the colon is to remove water from digested food prior to excretion.: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: A minimum level or position or degree; less than normal in degree, intensity or amount.
Denoting the front surface of the body; often used to indicate the position of one structure relative to another.

The part of the large intestine measured from the cecum to the rectum consisting of ascending, transverse, descending and sigmoid portions. The purpose of the colon is to remove water from digested food prior to excretion.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of the entire colon, anus, and rectum.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of the entire colon, anus, and rectum.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Added concept per TCGA request. mc 11/12/12

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of the entire colon.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of the entire colon.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The portion of the colon that connects to the descending colon above and the rectum below.: Surgical removal of part or all of the colon.

Concepts.definition: The portion of the colon that connects to the descending colon above and the rectum below.
Surgical removal of part or all of the colon.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of the transverse colon.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of the transverse colon.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Left; being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the west when facing north.: Surgical removal of approximately half of the colon.

Concepts.definition: Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the west when facing north.
Surgical removal of approximately half of the colon.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north.: Surgical removal of approximately half of the colon.: Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north.: Surgical removal of approximately half of the colon.

Concepts.definition: Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north.
Surgical removal of approximately half of the colon.
Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north.
Surgical removal of approximately half of the colon.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove part or all of an organ or a tumor and nearby lymph nodes. The incision is large enough to let the surgeon see into the body.: Surgery to remove part of one kidney or a kidney tumor, but not an entire kidney.

Concepts.definition: Surgery to remove part or all of an organ or a tumor and nearby lymph nodes. The incision is large enough to let the surgeon see into the body.
The surgical removal of a portion of a kidney.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove a kidney or part of a kidney. In a partial nephrectomy, part of one kidney or a tumor is removed, but not an entire kidney. In a simple nephrectomy, one kidney is removed. In a radical nephrectomy, an entire kidney, nearby adrenal gland and lymph nodes, and other surrounding tissue are removed. In a bilateral nephrectomy, both kidneys are removed.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure to completely or partially remove a kidney. With a complete nephrectomy, the attached adrenal gland, perinephric fat, and regional lymph nodes are often removed as well. With a partial nephrectomy, the removed tissue contains the tumor and a rim of normal renal parenchyma only.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of laparoscopic surgery where the surgeon uses both a laparoscope and his or her hand to help with dissection, retraction, and removal of tissue through a hand port incision.: Surgical removal of a kidney, the adrenal gland, adjacent lymph nodes, and other surrounding tissue.

Concepts.definition: A type of laparoscopic surgery where the surgeon uses both a laparoscope and his or her hand to help with dissection, retraction, and removal of tissue through a hand port incision.
Surgical removal of a kidney, the adrenal gland, adjacent lymph nodes, and other surrounding tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery done using a laparoscope.: Surgery to remove part of one kidney or a kidney tumor, but not an entire kidney.

Concepts.definition: Surgery done using a laparoscope.
The surgical removal of a portion of a kidney.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery done using a laparoscope.: Surgical removal of a kidney, the adrenal gland, adjacent lymph nodes, and other surrounding tissue.

Concepts.definition: Surgery done using a laparoscope.
Surgical removal of a kidney, the adrenal gland, adjacent lymph nodes, and other surrounding tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove part or all of an organ or a tumor and nearby lymph nodes. The incision is large enough to let the surgeon see into the body.: Surgical removal of a kidney, the adrenal gland, adjacent lymph nodes, and other surrounding tissue.

Concepts.definition: Surgery to remove part or all of an organ or a tumor and nearby lymph nodes. The incision is large enough to let the surgeon see into the body.
Surgical removal of a kidney, the adrenal gland, adjacent lymph nodes, and other surrounding tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery for breast cancer in which the breast, most or all of the lymph nodes under the arm, and the lining over the chest muscles are removed. Sometimes the surgeon also removes part of the chest wall muscles.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of one or both breasts, including the areola, nipple, and the majority of the axillary lymph nodes, but sparing the pectoralis major muscle.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical procedure involving the removal of the entire breast tissue, nipple and a portion of the overlying skin, while leaving the axillary contents intact.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure involving the removal of the entire breast tissue, nipple and a portion of the overlying skin, while leaving the axillary contents intact.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove abnormal tissue or cancer from the breast and a small amount of normal tissue around it. It is a type of breast-sparing surgery.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of a discrete mass.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of a triangular wedge shaped section of tissue.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of a triangular wedge shaped section of tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of a lobe of an organ.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of a lobe of an organ.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The excision of part or all of a lung.

Concepts.definition: The excision of part or all of a lung.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Endoscopic surgery of the pleural cavity performed with visualization via video transmission.

Concepts.definition: Thoracic surgery that is aided by the use of a video camera.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of surgical procedure in which a vertical inline incision is made along the sternum, after which the sternum itself is divided.
Situated at or extending to the side.: Surgical opening of the mediastinum.

Concepts.definition: Situated at or extending to the side.
A surgical procedure in which an large incision is made into the chest wall, for the purpose of accessing organs inside the thoracic cavity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

Concepts.definition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An incision shaped like a curved "W" typically performed in the anatomic skin and rib groove below the breasts.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products.:The process by which something is acquired or obtained.:A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products.
The process by which something is acquired or obtained.
A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
